The EU, meanwhile, has argued that US tech companies have abused tax loopholes.

“And oftentimes what is portrayed as high-minded positions on issues sometimes is just designed to carve out some of their commercial interests.”

In the past five years, the EU has targeted a number of US tech giants including Amazon, Apple, and Google with antitrust and tax-related penalties.

Trump isn’t the first to suggest that the EU has “taken advantage” of the US

Tech companies have long been at the center of a back-and-forth between the US and the EU, and Trump isn’t the first to suggest that they aren’t getting an even-handed shake.

In a tweet, he seemed to suggest that this penalty was yet another sign of the EU’s abuse of the US — an argument he’s increasingly stressed in recent days as he makes the case for imposing potential auto tariffs on the longtime American ally.

(Antitrust scrutiny on tech companies has grown in the US as well in the wake of Facebook’s Cambridge Analytica data privacy scandal and rising concerns that these giants have become too big too quickly.)

— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) July 19, 2018

The “Five Billion Dollar fine” Trump is referring to is a record penalty the EU levied against Google for antitrust violations this week.
“In a trade sense, they’ve really taken advantage of us, and many of those countries are in NATO and they weren’t paying their bills,” Trump said in a CBS News interview lambasting the EU.
Basically, the EU argues that Google forced phone makers to preinstall its Search and Browser apps onto Android phones, giving its products an unfair advantage over those of competitors.
Trump’s attack comes as the US continues to navigate a strained relationship with the EU, one of several allies that the president has become more combative with in the past month.
On Wednesday, the EU concluded a multiyear investigation and announced that it would punish Google for trying to bundle its own apps with its Android operating system.
“This point — that regulations are only there to shelter our companies — is out of line,” a European Commission spokesperson told the Financial Times.
Then- President Barack Obama had previously accused the EU of launching protectionist probes that took aim at American tech companies.

“It is in [US companies’] interest that things are enforced in a uniform manner.”

Our companies have created it, expanded it, perfected it in ways that they can’t compete,” Obama told Recode in 2015.
